Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Planning Reliable and Resilient Transportation Networks against Correlated Infrastructure Disruptions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project aims to discover a methodological framework that enhances the reliability and resilience of transportation network infrastructure systems that are exposed to multiple linked disruption risks. Such linked risks could be caused by exposure to common hazards or shared unreliable supplies. We will first establish a decomposition theory that transforms a general infrastructure system with linked facility disruption risks into one with a simpler and more explicit structure with only independent disruptions, yet ensuring that the two systems have exactly equivalent functionalities and operational behaviors. Based on this theoretical foundation, a set of advanced mathematical models will be created to address a number of pressing engineering challenges, including (i) reliable network design, (ii) critical infrastructure protection, and (iii) cascading failure mitigation. Case studies from real-world infrastructure systems (e.g., bridge networks exposed to earthquakes, electricity grids experiencing power plant disruptions) will be used to validate the proposed theory and illustrate the practical applicability of these models.

If successful, the results of this research will (i) advance the knowledge base needed to address a wide range of infrastructure disruptions in many engineering contexts, (ii) provide managerial insights that hold the promise of enhancing the reliability and resilience of various infrastructure systems. This will have impacts not only on transportation and manufacturing industries but also on social communities. This project will also result in new educational practices by the integration of the research into educational materials and activities, including a new role-playing game for interactive teaching focused on infrastructure disruption mechanisms and protection strategies. Collaborations with public agencies (e.g. state Departments of Transportation) and private freight and manufacturing industries (e.g. CSX Transportation Inc. and Caterpillar Inc.) will help assure that the proposed research and educational activities are of practical relevance and importance, and that the outcomes are readily implementable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has established a unified theory to characterize general interdependences and correlations of individual service facilities such that reliable system design and robust critical infrastructure protection against correlated disruption risks due to random or intentional attacks become possible. We have also examined dynamic propagation mechanisms of correlated disruptions, and devise strategies for resilient infrastructure systems that can resist such propagation and restore system functions. We have synergized the research efforts into a number of educational developments (e.g., new graduate courses and certificate programs, interactive game software) and outreach activities (e.g., to undergraduate, minority, K-12 schools and industry). Some of the key outcomes are listed below.

General decomposition scheme for disruption correlations: We propose a new methodology framework for analyzing and modeling facility disruptions with general correlations (including negative correlations). This framework first proposes pairwise transformations between three probabilistic representations (i.e., conditional, marginal, and scenario probabilities) of general correlations (including both positive and negative correlations) among multiple distributed facilities. The proposed transformation equations unify different representations of spatial disruption correlations. Then the proposed framework decomposes these representations of correlation into an equivalent supporting station structure consisting of a set of stations with only independent disruptions. This decomposition scheme enables to describe complex correlated disruptions with much simpler independent disruptions and thus largely reduces the efforts to evaluate performance and optimize configurations for systems involving correlated disruptions. We analytically show several critical properties for the transformations between the three correlation representations and for the decomposition into the supporting station structure. A set of numerical case studies are conducted to illustrate the detailed transformation and decomposition steps, and to show the applicability of our proposed framework.

 

Facility location design under general correlation: We consider facility disruptions that exhibit correlations, which arise either from shared external hazards (or direct interactions) among these facilities, or indirectly via failures of underlying infrastructures that support multiple facilities. We build an overarching methodological framework for reliable facility location design under generally correlated facility disruptions, using the decomposition framework that we developed last year. The stations can either be actual supporting infrastructures, or be virtual additions to the system for capturing the effect of shared hazards. We then develop a compact mixed-integer mathematical model to optimize the facility locations and customer assignment decisions in order to strike a balance between system reliability and cost efficiency. Lagrangian relaxation based algorithms, including approximation subroutines for relaxed subproblems, are proposed to effectively solve the proposed model. Numerical case studies are carried out to test the performance of the modeling framework, and to draw managerial insights. 

Cascading failure equilibrium in infrastructure systems: Disruptions often propagate within and across multiple infrastructure networks and result in catastrophic consequences. The reaction of population communities to disasters (e.g., seeking alternatives) may further transfer and aggravate the burden on surviving infrastructures, which may facilitate cascading secondary disruptions. Hence, a holistic analysis framework that integrates infrastructure interdependencies and human community behaviors is needed to evaluate a city’s vulnerability to disruptions and to assess the impact of a disaster. To this end, we develop a game-theoretical equilibrium model in a multi-layer infrastructure network to systematically investigate the mutual influence between the infrastructures and the communities. Two types of infrastructure failure patterns are formulated to capture general network interdependencies; network equilibrium is extended into infrastructure and community systems to address redistribution of demand for life-supporting resources; the societal impact of disasters is estimated based on communities’ resource demand loss, cost increase, as well as total infrastructure failure. A real-world case study on Maiduguri, Nigeria, is implemented to demonstrate the proposed model and algorithm, and to reveal insights.

Outcomes of the research activities have been reported to research community, industry partners and students through journal publications, national and international conferences and other outreach efforts. We collected national disaster data to complete a large-scale temporal-spatial disaster database.
